item.title: Canada's polygamy laws upheld by B.C. Supreme Court
item.description: B.C. Supreme Court upholds Canada's polygamy laws, but says minors who end up in polygamous marriages should be exempt from prosecution.

item.title: Arctic sea ice loss unprecedented in 1,450 years
item.description: The recent loss of sea ice in the Arctic is greater than any natural variation in the past 1Â½ millennia, a Canadian study shows.

item.title: DNA match found in B.C. Halloween slaying
item.description: Police have made a DNA match to a male suspect and have released an old composite sketch of him in connection to the slaying of a B.C. teenager on Halloween night.

item.title: Carney says firms should invest, despite turmoil
item.description: Bank of Canada governor Mark Carney says growing access to capital should make Canadian businesses confident to invest, despite the financial chaos that has rocked Europe and troubling signals out of the United States.

item.title: 'Suicidal' Shafia daughter described by school official
item.description: School and youth protection officials tell a quadruple-murder trial in Kingston, Ont., that the middle Shafia daughter thought of suicide, feared her parents and claimed they physically abused her.

item.title: George Clooney asked to testify at Berlusconi sex trial
item.description: George Clooney is among more than 200 witnesses accepted by a Milan court in the trial of former premier Silvio Berlusconi for allegedly paying for sex with an underage prostitute.

item.title: CBC must hand over files to information watchdog
item.description: CBC must hand over documents to Canada's information commissioner, the Federal Court of Appeal has ruled in a battle over access to information.

item.title: Occupy Toronto tents come down peacefully
item.description: The Occupy Toronto encampment comes to a peaceful end with protesters vacating the last occupied tent in St. James Park after a negotiated settlement with police.

item.title: Hells Angels-linked drug raids target 4 cells
item.description: More than two-dozen people were arrested Wednesday during large-scale drug-trafficking raids in Quebec and New Brunswick that authorities say could neutralize an organized crime ring linked to the Hells Angels.

item.title: Canadian acquitted in Jamaican throat-slashing trial
item.description: A Catholic school teacher from Ajax, Ont. accused of trying to murder his wife in Jamaica in December 2010 has been acquitted by a jury.

item.title: Egypt's military rulers faulted as clash toll rises
item.description: Egyptian police clash with anti-government protesters for a fifth day in Cairo, as a rights group raises the overall death toll to 38 and the UN condemns what it calls excessive force by authorities.

item.title: Flaherty sets updates to financial laws
item.description: The federal government is moving ahead with changes to laws governing Canada's financial institutions that will give Ottawa greater authority over foreign acquisitions.

item.title: Snowstorm slams the Maritimes
item.description: The first big snowfall of the season is wreaking havoc on the Maritimes, with treacherous driving conditions, cancelled flights, power outages and a growing number of school closures and rescheduled events.

item.title: Canada scores low in patient safety
item.description: Canada fares well compared with other OECD countries for quitting smoking, but has some of the worst rates for patient safety such as leaving in foreign bodies during surgery, according to a new report.

item.title: Clement stands by G8 testimony
item.description: NDP MPs Charlie Angus and Alexandre Boulerice accused Treasury Board president Tony Clement of misleading Parliament when he appeared at a committee about his role in the G8 legacy fund.
